key_risks: Legal and regulatory risks, including class action lawsuits and antitrust litigation
Intense market competition from rivals like Squarespace, Wix, and Bluehost
Slowing growth and potential overvaluation concerns
Dependence on third-party partnerships for critical operations
controversies: $35 million settlement over unwanted text messages, now under reconsideration
Antitrust lawsuit alleging anti-competitive practices in domain services
Customer backlash over support for the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA)
Criticism over unclear pricing practices and aggressive upselling
environmental_issues: Commitment to using 100% renewable energy for data centers by 2025
social_issues: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor support quality and pricing transparency
Concerns about data privacy and handling of customer information
governance_issues: Regulatory compliance challenges across multiple jurisdictions
Potential financial liabilities from ongoing legal disputes

sources.title: Controversies surrounding GoDaddy - Wikipedia
sources.snippet: In 2002, GoDaddy sued VeriSign for domain slamming [1] and again in 2003 over its Site Finder service. [2] This latter suit caused controversy over VeriSign's role as the sole maintainer of the .com and .net top-level domains.VeriSign shut down Site Finder after receiving a letter from ICANN ordering it to comply with a request to disable the service. [3] ...

sources.title: DNS company files antitrust lawsuit against GoDaddy
sources.snippet: A company that helps domain owners update DNS records has filed an antitrust lawsuit against GoDaddy (NYSE: GDDY). Entri acts as a conduit between SaaS companies and domain registrars. If a customer needs to update their domain's DNS records to work with an email provider, site builder, or other SaaS business, they can use a wizard directly on the SaaS company's website to make these changes.
